body: @zengzhihai110 This is a very vague question. What exactly are you confused about? Have you tried the tutorials?
您能听懂中文吗？我英文不大好。那个官方文档，我按照上面的走，都不能正常的按照那个的结果显示出来，你能给下更好地方式让我明白安装druid的 过程吗？
LGTM
@himanshug It would be nice if we can also add an integration-test for batch ingestion.
tracked by #1609
minor comment, but LGTM otherwise
@drcrallen we should also update guice version in druid-api while we're at it for consistency, and update druid-api version
@xvrl : https://github.com/druid-io/druid-api/pull/51
+1 after travis passes.

@zengzhihai110 

我可以讲中文，但是我们希望用英文来作为主要语言，以方便Druid社区查询问题。在线有一些教程可以帮助你理解Druid setup：http://druid.io/docs/0.8.0/tutorials/index.html 。Druid是一个分布式系统，所以我很难用短篇的中文来解释setup的过程，最好的方法还是学习在线教程。

－－－

I do speak Chinese but we prefer to keep the language here in English so the community can easily search for issues. There are a few tutorials related to setting up Druid for the first time: http://druid.io/docs/0.8.0/tutorials/index.html. Druid is a distributed system so it is very difficult for me to write a short summary of how you can set it up without you spending some time to learn about the system.
ok  thank you
You can also ask questions and get help through our user group: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/druid-user
thank you very much
@himanshug putting hdfs-storage extension in the druid configuration

by the way, Kerberos auth have a expire time, with the command 'kinit', the auth info can be renewed, if I didn't run 'kinit' after the expire time, Druid will fail with a auth failed exception.  

Question is if Druid deal with the auth issue or there is any config options to solve the problem?

Currently, I use crontab to run the 'kinit' command periodically, but I don't think it's a good fix.

@onlychoice
1) I have noticed many problems with hadoop classloader being different. As a workaround, instead of adding hdfs-storage as extension in the configuration, can you try to include the druid-hdfs-storage and all the hadoop configuration, dependencies (that can be obtained by running command `hadoop classpath` on a machine where hadoop has been setup) in the classpath. And, provide necessary HDFS settings as described in Deep Storage ( http://druid.io/docs/latest/dependencies/deep-storage.html )  . Then auth should work without any of the code changes.

2) regarding the problem with auth expiration, can you try to specify following environment variables to the druid java process.. (and that should let druid automatically do the periodic kinits without you having to do anything externally like cron)
KRB5KEYTAB=/path/to/keytab/file
KRB5PRINCIPAL=your-krb5-principal
Sounds good, we can merge this as soon as druid-api with updated guice is released, and druid-api version has been updated in this PR.
Believed fixed by #1427
@himanshug / @onlychoice Beware of #1016 with such an approach

@drcrallen thanks, #1016 looks related to specifying same extension in both configuration and manually on the classpath. things should be fine if hdfs-storage is removed from properties file and only put on the classpath.
@guobingkun any updates on this? Since we'll be releasing 0.8.1 soon, it would be nice not to have a known regression in it
Was busy with other stuff. Will take a look this week.
build is expected to fail until the release for druid-api finishes.
@xvrl travis is passing here.

I investigated a bit and the bug has something to do with this commit - https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1465
`fs.open(pt)` at https://github.com/gianm/druid/blob/4a3a7dd1adf892f3fda75681e04e10851083ca15/indexing-hadoop/src/main/java/io/druid/indexer/HadoopDruidIndexerConfig.java#L184 causes the local index task to fail. I didn't spend much time on it so I am still not sure why `fs.open()` is causing it to fail as this line is not exercised during the local indexing task. As a workaround I am passing in `null` in `InputStreamReader` constructor (It is not the solution) so that I can continue my work.
Thanks @pjain1, @gianm do you have any idea what might be broken here?
I agree with  number 1, it fits in better with my Tiering proposal for tasks as well.

Generally :+1: assuming someone has checked that delta ingestion with metrics that have different regular vs combining aggs does work. It would be nice to have a test for delta ingestion in the same vein as the IndexGeneratorJobTest.

Just to be different, I like 2 because it would catch more problems. A worker that is broken in some other way than just all tasks immediately failing won't be caught by method 1. But either one is better than nothing so I am not picky.

IMHO the worker should be responsible for reporting its own status. And different types of workers would have different criteria for "healthy".

Obviously the overlord should have some level of "Can't even reach the middle manager" case handling.

@drcrallen  not certain but this PR seems to be causing following exception in hadoop batch ingestion (I'm using hadoop-2.6)

are you successfully being able to run hadoop ingestion after this update?
@himanshug Using my simple test of `index hadoop index-test.json` through my IntelliJ setup seems to work fine. Still investigating to see if the indexing service has something weird with this update
@himanshug Specifying `"hadoopCoordinates": "org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client:2.6.0"` seems to be working locally. for the indexing service

@drcrallen hmmm, not sure yet, but I have a hadoop-2.6 cluster deployed . ran druid processes with `hadoop classpath` output and hdfs-storage on classpath. doing the ingestion using HadoopIndexTask via overlord and it failed on me, removing the 2 commits from this PR solved the problem.
@himanshug can you make sure nothing in your build or extensions is pulling in an older version of guice? This seems like somewhere on your classpath an older version of guice got pulled in.

@xvrl that is true, "hadoop classpath" would include guice jar bundled with hadoop deployment, which will be guice-3.0 .
I think, probably I'm facing the issue because both guice-4.0 and guice-3.0 are ending up being on the classpath. In this case I'm using druid-services-0.8.1-SNAPSHOT-selfcontained.jar which will have guice-4.0 classes inside it.
Sorry, for letting you wait, but I'm currently on parental leave. Let me know if I did it correct. (first time for me to contribute to a big project).

do they both run on same container in parallel?
@nishantmonu51 yes

LGTM and I am OK adding it to 0.8.1

looks like it might be a transient issue in ubuntu servers. 
Is it reproducible or does it shows often ?

I like both. But, I would go for 1 because it is more self-contained within the worker and simpler to implement. Also, It will be great to increase the scope of 1 a little bit to track count of consecutive failures (for any tasks assigned to it and not just the sanity task, and disable itself if there were too many consecutive failures.
In future, We can evolve towards 2 if/when we notice cases not caught by 1.

looks ok to me overall on first glance

Here is the task log https://gist.github.com/guobingkun/6025d9b0afa3edfe8e6e for the realtime task. At 2015-08-13T22:34:22,824, TimedShutoffFirehose was shutting down.

also, @guobingkun is going to try this out on our test cluster to see if it fixes the problem we noticed

interesting, test passes here in the travis build and in ide as well,
but failed on another machine with the error that
java.io.FileNotFoundException: File 'file:/home/himanshu/.m2/repository/io/druid/druid-processing/0.8.1-SNAPSHOT/druid-processing-0.8.1-SNAPSHOT-tests.jar!/druid.sample.tsv' does not exist

it seems, in certain cases druid.sample.tsv (present in a different, druid-processing-[version]-tests.jar) might not be readable.
@himanshug Showed up in our dogfood cluster. Reverting until IT can be fixed to catch issue.
@drcrallen makes sense to revert till we figure out the root cause.
need to figure out and fix why druid.sample.tsv reading failed in one case.
@himanshug we can try reducing parallelism. I do notice that builds tend to fail less often when building independently, so we may be running into races between the two builds somewhere.
@himanshug I reduced travis build concurrency to 1, let's see if this works, or if it causes things to become unbearably slow. Let's reopen if it remains an issue.

@himanshug I do have a concern about concurrency here, if I use delta ingestion but do not have a lock on the interval, then whatever I ingest may or may not be actually representative of the latest data. A simple example is if I run delta ingestion twice at the same time for different input paths to add. (or start a second one before the first has finished).

The indexing service hadoop indexer should be handling locks correctly, and I think such a race condition should not be able to proceed when the indexing service is used.

But the standalone hadoop indexer could very easily encounter a race. But since we in general do not support accounting for race conditions in the stand alone stuff, that is just how its going to be.

Does that sound correct?

@drcrallen that sounds right to me. The stance on standalone stuff (hadoop & realtime) has always been that you need to think about consistency and concurrency yourself, since Druid only does meaningful locking when you use the indexing service.

@drcrallen wrt concurrency, that is true. But, this PR is not introducing/changing that behavior. The issue you described with standalone hadoop indexer is there even today and not related to this PR really.
FWIW, I am not a fan of standalone hadoop indexer and would rather see it go away. It is generally painful to maintain multiple ways of doing same thing. Also, it confuses users and we see email threads about explaining the differences between 2 kind of hadoop ingestion.
@himanshug / @gianm Cool, I'm good with maintaining existing behavior, and just wanted to make sure our expectations are documented in case anyone ever comes back to this PR's comment thread.
@xvrl I am wondering if we can disable java-8 build as well. We don't release java-8 compiled artifacts so it is not really necessary for now. We will need it once druid switches to java-8 exclusive.

@gianm @drcrallen @nishantmonu51 
I have made the change now so that DatasourcePathSpec gets List of segments instead of UsedSegmentLister instance. HadoopIndexTask and CliInternalHadoopIndexer use overlord action and metadata store respectively to get the list of segments and pass down.
Since, we are not playing with setting things at class level anymore , so classloader issues dont creep up.
I did test it both ways (with and without hadoop libs on overlord classpath) and standalone hadoop indexer.
If you would like to just see the related changes made, please see https://github.com/himanshug/druid/commit/22228c2acf8496858ffc388f9ab9a68889ddcaef
I have rebased things, so this is ready to merge (unless someone notices some other problem) :)

Good point made by Nishant. I was hyper-focused on getting access to the "resource" node. :grinning: It does make more sense to use the existing constructor. I've force-pushed a new submission which leaves the abstract unchanged and does the needful from IndexTask.
@Hailei, It would be great if you can also add a unit test to GroupByQueryRunnerTest for this.

@MrAlias How are you setting the config in your properties file? Are you sure the config is being included in the classpath when you start the node?

I think  this is  a bug,But this PR isn't good solution.
The reason why this query of output is empty: inner query group by 'cast'  and 'device' two dimensions, and  outer query only group by 'device',meanwhile filter 'cast' dimension.
as following code

``` java
 // We need the inner incremental index to have all the columns required by the outer query
      final GroupByQuery innerQuery = new GroupByQuery.Builder(subquery)
          .setAggregatorSpecs(aggs)
          .setInterval(subquery.getIntervals())
          .setPostAggregatorSpecs(Lists.<PostAggregator>newArrayList())
          .build();

     IncrementalIndex index = makeIncrementalIndex(innerQuery, subqueryResult);
```

If inner query group by outer query's GROUP BY,the increment index only contains 'cast',So can't filter by 'cast=1'

Use inner query to make increment index is redundant,their GROUP BY is the same,So this PR isn't good solution
The PR in question has been closed down until a proper replacement for Remote Task Runner is implemented.

Thanks for the reply @fjy.

com.google.inject.ProvisionException: Guice provision errors:

...
```

I tried combining all the configuration values into _common.runtime.properties_ and it appeared to fix the issue, as the service no longer failed with the memory error.

I likely have missed something, but I did think that it was possible to specify configurations in different properties files.  I remember doing this when I was first playing around with the shipped druid examples.  Is there a reason _/etc/druid/historical.runtime.properties_ would not be loaded given this setup?

@MrAlias I wonder if this is a silly bug in the code, but what happens if you rename historical.runtime.properties to just runtime.properties and make sure it comes after the common.runtime.properties in the classpath?

Yes! That fixes it:

```
$ /usr/bin/java -server -Xmx512m -Xms512m -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC -XX:+PrintGCDetails -XX:+PrintGCTimeStamps -Duser.timezone=UTC -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -Djava.util.logging.manager=org.apache.logging.log4j.jul.LogManager -classpath :/etc/druid/common.runtime.properties:/etc/druid/runtime.properties:/usr/local/lib/druid/lib/* io.druid.cli.Main server historical
2015-08-18T16:50:45,651 INFO [main] io.druid.guice.PropertiesModule - Loading properties from common.runtime.properties
2015-08-18T16:50:45,664 INFO [main] io.druid.guice.PropertiesModule - Loading properties from runtime.properties
1.517: [GC1.517: [DefNew: 68160K->6967K(76672K), 0.0202210 secs] 68160K->6967K(515776K), 0.0206200 secs] [Times: user=0.03 sys=0.00, real=0.02 secs] 
2015-08-18T16:50:46,517 INFO [main] io.druid.guice.JsonConfigurator - Loaded class[class io.druid.guice.ExtensionsConfig] from props[druid.extensions.] as [ExtensionsConfig{searchCurrentClassloader=true, coordinates=[], defaultVersion='0.8.0', localRepository='~/.m2/repository', remoteRepositories=[http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/, https://metamx.artifactoryonline.com/metamx/pub-libs-releases-local]}]

...
```

This ran without errors and looks to be loading the configuration in _/etc/druid/runtime.properties_ fine.

It does appear that the name of the file is important, not just the classpath ordering.  I tried the same ordering of the classpath after moving back to the original properties file name (_/etc/druid/historical.runtime.properties_) which failed to load:

```
$ /usr/bin/java -server -Xmx512m -Xms512m -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC -XX:+PrintGCDetails -XX:+PrintGCTimeStamps -Duser.timezone=UTC -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -Djava.util.logging.manager=org.apache.logging.log4j.jul.LogManager -classpath :/etc/druid/common.runtime.properties:/etc/druid/historical.runtime.properties:/usr/local/lib/druid/lib/* io.druid.cli.Main server historical
2015-08-18T16:54:57,417 INFO [main] io.druid.guice.PropertiesModule - Loading properties from common.runtime.properties
1.466: [GC1.466: [DefNew: 68160K->6963K(76672K), 0.0208670 secs] 68160K->6963K(515776K), 0.0212810 secs] [Times: user=0.03 sys=0.00, real=0.03 secs]
